@0xShual @0xFrensdly From my understanding, you can determine the contracts address in advance, so I'm guessing the token creator:

1. Determined the contract that would become the "araWallet"
2. Deployed the token contract with that address in the constructor
3. Deployed the malicious contract

Whenever I go through my historic txs and wallet history and see a spam transaction I play a little game with myself called 'Guess the blockchain this happened on'

But it's a very easy game because the answer 99.9% of the time is ‚Äî polygon.

Controversial take, maybe:

Nobody cares to fix airdrop distributions because the downside of strict criteria is far worse than giving a bunch to sybillors. If you end up not giving to like 1% of vocal people due to overcutting - that is worse than giving 50% to sybillors.

Now let's have a look at Jito.

Smallest Account: 100 pts, 4941 tokens, $3 VWAP first cpl days -> $15,000

Largest Account: 92.1MM points, 104391 tokens, ~$315,000

If largest account divided into 92,100 accounts with 100 points, he'd have gotten most of airdrop.

if 92 accounts‚Ä¶ https://t.co/E3JntmnvbB

It's ludicrous to me that projects this size, harnessing the sum of all the brain power at their disposal to build tokenomics, didn't crunch the numbers to ensure this type of shit can't happen. They have visibility on ALL the data.

I therefore must assume this was the intent.
